>Will having no social media affect my chances of meeting women or getting a girlfriend
Sure, just by the mere principal that you're just meeting less people. You'll always be able to meet and interact with a larger volume of people over the internet than you will just in real life.

>will they be weirded out?
The real purpose of social media is a kind of vetting process. Having social media in and of itself is not the purpose - the purpose is that by having a social media girls get to look at your profile and get a sense of who you are. If you post nothing but pictures of you sitting alone in your room and portraits of your body pillow collection she'll know to stay away. If she looks at your profile and sees pictures of you hanging out with friends, going to events, exploring the outdoors, engaging in hobbies etc., she can roughly gather that you aren't a complete schizoid loser and that people agreeing to be in a photo smiling with you means you're capable of building and maintaining relationships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28252751
What are you really looking for? Genuine connections? On 4chan?
That's a risky business good sir; it's a high risk low reward venture, that's for sure.
There used to be a few threads that had a community of sorts behind them on this board; and a few other boards around 4chan as well. But you don't really see that too much anymore.
And probably for good reason as mixing too many periphery personalities into one place inevitably leads to combustion. And the word combustion scarcely describes what happens when a 4chan-based community blows up. Though it may be fun at first, it's probably something best avoided

With 4chan it's hard to get close to people: there are no DMs and there are very few people filling out the name field (all good things in my opinion) which means most interactions are ephemeral and rarely done for external ego building. That doesn't mean people who are Anonymous don't post simply to stroke their egos; there are quite a number of people who do.
However, with anonymity, people do tend to lower their guard, just a bit, which makes it possible for a genuine interaction to occur. And its these genuine, fleeting interactions which have kept me coming back to this site for uh.. oh boy.. yeah, for about 18 years now.

I like /adv/ because people come here in search for others who are feeling how they feel; people who can share their burden and in doing so ease it a bit. Even if people can't really help at all, the simple act of being acknowledged goes a long way for many.

While I'm satisfied with this level of interaction you're probably wanting more, and that's ok. However, I don't know if 4chan is the best way to go about making such lasting friendships. Are there are other generals or boards out there where you can find what you're looking for? I don't thinks so, I think you're on the right board for what you're looking for; however, it might take one of those rare, almost magical threads for it to happen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28252956
You're a neophyte to the field, with training and discipline comes mastery and with mastery all of these fears and uncertainties will fade away.

If you love it then immerse yourself in it; and you can start right now if you want. One of my favorite channels on YouTube is called NinjaNerd. This guy is a total savant in the areas of biochemistry, anatomy, physiology, biology and the like. He's also one of the most knowledgeable people that I've ever encountered in real life or on the internet:

https://www.youtube.com/@NinjaNerdOfficial/

Though most of his content is human-related, a lot of this knowledge carries over to other mammalian creatures. I think it would be a good way to get yourself prepped for what's to come as a little knowledge goes a long way in dispelling fear and anxiety.
Now if you decide to try to get immersed in some of his starter videos, remember this: don't try to remember everything. Just simply watch it, maybe watch it twice. It helps to be around people talking in the language of your field of study. Simply being around it, hearing the terms, seeing the diagrams and things of that nature; these all help considerably with getting yourself immersed within your field of study. With immersion you don't just study a field, you become apart of the field which you're studying. And with that level of immersion mastery can begin to take form.

As for the pay, the vets in my area are making a very nice living. I'm not sure where you live but you may want to consider moving to a wealthier area where the vet clinics make sure you don't walk out without paying in excess of $300.00 per visit. I hate it, but for you, as a future vet, you can make a killing. Not the pets of course!

>>28254023
I used to be a barman in my early 20's and ended up an early adopter of alcoholism.
After several years of almost daily drunkenness I quit in three months. The first month was simply reducing my drinking until i was only drinking a bottle of vodka per day, this wasn't hard because i was still reasonably drunk, i just stopped blacking out every night.
The second month i tried a bunch of things unsuccessfully, having sober days, switching to lighter beer, not going out. I relapsed twice.
The third month through a combination of attempts i was drinking about 3/4 of a bottle of vodka a day and decided to go cold turkey. I only made three days, but was back in the wagon the day after and I've been three years sober.

My life is now boring as fuck, I've got little excuse to get out of the house, I'm still unemployed. But I've got money and an behaving decently again, so mixed results.

So i would recommend reducing your drinking to a sensible level then going cold Turkey. If you drink heavily it's very important not to go cold Turkey immediately because you can suffer acute alcohol withdrawal

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're GOOD at it, it doesn't matter the area, you will find a job once word gets out that you're a good employee. Passion is the leading factor for being excellent, so Compsci in this case.

However, working is different from learning and even different from executing the craft.
I for one found my passion (drawing) and my work (commercial art) did not correlate very well. I hate doing what I love as a job, so I started working with something I feel more comfortable, more "natural" at (teaching) and turned my main interest into more of a hobby/side-activity.

Mind you, the pay with art was higher because I was getting somewhere, but it was not worth the mental strain.
Think about the jobs you'd be motivated to clock in at every day, think about your personality and what makes you productive.
A big part of why art sucked for me, other than "realizing other people's vision", was the fact that I suck at being an independent worker. I need a schedule to push me to do things, teaching people I can't "do it later".

Disregard all of this if you're on a real pinch for a job/money ASAP. But if it's more of a long-term life thing, consider you'll be doing it for decades and be mindful of your quality of life, mentally speaking.

posts.sub: In this thread we are going to look for the cure for depression
posts.com:
I have no proof or medical studies to show that this is the case, but I also have no doubts. I believe that to get out of depression, tiredness, fatigue and all that shit, you first have to work your body, since a healthy body is a healthy mind, for that it is good to do sports, whatever it is. it is as long as it keeps our body busy. Another important factor is studying, it doesn't really matter what, it doesn't matter if it's for university, school or for yourself, you have to do it to keep your mind occupied with something productive. I would also say that looking for a job, or generating income with a startup, as this will keep our mind and body busy, while giving us money, in itself gives us a reason to keep going, especially when you are working on something of your own.

Another important point is to stop comparing yourself to others, stop thinking that the other is better than you because you have more knowledge, money or physical condition. It is also very silly to think about issues such as superiority or inferiority, we are all human, we all have problems and difficulties in life, of course there are degrees of this, but this does not have to be a limitation. You have to focus on yourself, on your problems, on your virtues, on your life, and not on that of others.

Another issue is guilt and remorse, which depending on the person can be the easiest part, or difficult to overcome, because it is easy to forgive others, but sometimes it is difficult, if not impossible, to forgive yourself. No matter how dirty your hands are, they can always be cleaned. You have to accept your sins, accept what you did wrong and live with it. Go to a priest, a psychologist, or tell someone you trust what you did, this can help, it doesn't matter if you think psychology is a joke, or if you don't believe in God, the important thing is to somehow get the weight off What are you wearing.

posts.name: op
posts.com: think you need to begin with the question of why do people in general feel emotions to begin to answer why someone would fall into a perpetual negative emotional state. Emotions are clearly intrinsic instincts not learned although learned experiences can change what triggers the emotions to occur. These instincts evolved over time to prod people towards the actions that have proven to be evolutionarily successful over time. Because people are highly social animals and there is fierce competition between different social groups of people, many of the emotions we feel are actually designed to not simply benefit yourself and improve your own survival, but to benefit the survival of the entire social group. These instincts go hand in hand with developed cultural mores.

>>28220657
It all comes down to conditioning.

From the most recent trigger or episode to your emotional trauma that sets off depression.
Or the cycle of trauma and pain you repeat and keep yourself in.
Down to traumatic events that have a lifelong impact on your psyche.

The necessary systems in place for recovery are 'safety', 'hope of recovery and future', an environment that fosters these two things as well as the social justice aspect, meaning you get the recognition of trauma you were dealt and the perpetrator dealt with. (but in the case of Act of God events, it's rationalisation through the reality of what happened)

This means, identifying things in your environment and social groups as well as your past, that negatively affect you. Doing your best to distance and remove those obstacles in your life and then having the 'stability' of an environment that is conducive to positive feedback cycles and a normalisation of ptsd behaviour responses in order to become and feel normal.

Lack of hope is another big reason, but this falls back to conditioning and a lack of positive feedback cycles fueling your worldview. If your metaphysical understanding of the universe is lacking, you won't see the point of your individualism in the big picture.
>seek god
>or develop another useful schema (evolution)


Depression is just when life beats you down and you lack the insight and motivation or opportunity to actually make a change. It's as simple as that.
And if you say your family has a history of depression, then that's just generational conditioning that has left your psyche disordered in order to grow somehow. Your ancestors fought through their environments to overcome depression, as should you etc.

My depression started when I was 13 years old, I didn't bathe, I had constant nightmares, I didn't eat, I was sad and with a feeling of emptiness all the time. I didn't really have any strong trauma, I lived a good life in general, but the fear of death, the fear of emptiness and knowing that everything we know would vanish, really terrified me, made me sad, and not wanting to do anything. We cannot say whether or not you should take antidepressants, you must attend one or two sessions with a psychiatrist and tell him about your problems, and he will determine whether or not you have depression. You can be a functional, charismatic person, who bathes, goes to work, studies, and does everything well, but if apathy (loss of interest in things), a feeling of emptiness, and physical symptoms such as fatigue from nothing , then you may have depression, especially with those suicidal thoughts that you have.
Therapy can also help, but if you go to several sessions, tell them all your problems and see that it doesn't help you, it's better to change someone better. Do not stay with the first option, if you do not like something you are always free to go and change.

>>28216868
Here’s you. You don’t know yourself very well.

And over there is society, your parents, peers etc. Tv screens, schools… They’ve been telling you all your life what a “good person” is. Maybe you felt you are not good enough the way you are.

That causes trauma. Sounds dramatic, but all it means is that pain causes you to reject certain aspects of yourself.

This rejection functions by repression, preventing who you are from being made conscious. And therefore you have low self-awareness. You also have a feeling of need. You don’t feel whole.

For the places where you rejected yourself, you do not know what you really want. You’ve disconnected from yourself. Instead, what you’re doing is aspiring to make yourself conform to the image society has programmed onto you. This is the trap of self-image.

The maintenance of a self-image is a burden, motivated by anxiety and pain. You may be good at it, or you may be so handicapped by it, that it extinguishes you, and it completely prevents you from knowing what you actually want.

In the latter example, you are sure you know what you want, you just “can’t get yourself to do it”. It is the poor self-awareness at work, because of the trauma. And that is how you get depressed.

It is getting stuck in a lie, that you are unwilling to let go of (that you have to be/do better), because you are sure that you are worthless as you are.

>>28216868
I think the most important thing is a combination of social support and validation.

Some seek validation through sex or long-term relationships, or through their careers. Without this, people will doubt themselves and have low confidence. Sometimes validation can be internal, but that requires an unusually strong moral foundation and a lot of willpower. Most people will seek this through social interactions. I honestly believe that being romantically valued is vital to a persons mental health - you are being judged by another person and found worthy of their commitment and attention. Social media is being used as a replacement for IRL validation, and we all see how that's going.

The requirement for social support is a phycological need to know that you have a safety net (social, emotional and physical) in case something goes wrong that you can't handle on your own. If you don't have this support you'll be subconsciously aware of your own vulnerability to disasters, like medical emergencies or times of hardship. Humans are pack animals, and knowing that you have a "tribe" that has your back is a very primal need for us. The state to some extent has fulfilled the "physical" aspect, but not the emotional or social.

In my experience both personal and from observing others, these two needs are absolute and cannot be replaced. Trying to substitute them with other distractions is only a temporary measure and will eventually fail.

I've been depressed for 3 years or so. Started with COVID lockdowns.

The first year, I had no idea I was depressed. I just kinda lost motivation, lost focus, lost memory. I ate a lot more, was impulsive, lost all my passions. Probably one of the last symptoms I got was just feeling numb all the time.

I need to go to the dentist because I wasn't brushing my teeth. And there a whole bunch of shitty effects (I am poorer, fatter, etc)


I have never recovered to my previous self, but I know that the gym really helps me. I take Adderall, but the effect barely works now, but it's good enough. I think changing your environment and doing novel things also helps.


I think depression stems from various things. But being lonely, feeling as if you have no possessions, feeling trapped/lack of control, etc are all big factors. Things start to spiral, and shit gets worse. Every day feels the same, and like a chore, etc.

In my case, my family & lack of friends/clubs seem to be the problem. But I'm kinda stuck (which is also a problem).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28246463
>i just dont have the energy or drive to do anything.

Not the anon you're talking to, but this is one part of the mindset that you have to break. A major part.

My advice is to just do that thing you should be doing, whether you feel like you have the energy or not. Your brain actively works against you when you're depressed. Sometimes you have to ignore what it's telling you, which sometimes means forcing yourself to ignore every thought beyond "I should do that thing".

When you've done the thing you need to congratulate yourself. Even if you think the thing is ultimately inconsequential or so small it isn't worth it, the fact is that you did it, and that's more than you were able to do yesterday. And that's what will lead to progress.

Start small, with things you can do right now with no preparation. Work up to the big stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28245020
All kinds of fasting will do it. All kinds of out of the ordinary activities do it to varying extents. Everything is best done without any expectations. Including nofap if you want to try it anyway. Something as simple as planting a plant. Otherwise, if you can go to a fight gym, that definitely will. If you have a cold ocean you can get in for a few minutes, you literally cannot exit the same mood you entered. Showers as cold as they’ll go, in my opinion, are both less effective and more torturous, but they’ll do it if there’s no ocean. And if you like the ocean, you can build an ice tub from a freezer fairly simply.

Also, I think one important thing I learned was that my idea of getting better… It was far too based in the depression itself. I took the depression too seriously, so a lot of the hopeful moments I had were actually just the other side of the same coin, and they reinforced the depression. Actually getting better was much more about cooling the jets, and learning to let go of that thinking a little bit. Pulling your emotional investments out of the depression AND the hope. Having less need to control it, assigning less meaning to it, understanding that you cannot FIX it. Getting over it truly isn’t about fixing anything, which can be very difficult to begin to understand.

It’s much more about allowing yourself to start thinking some lighter thoughts, allowing yourself to trust them, not needing them to become true today or tomorrow, but just gently enjoying the feeling of trusting something a little bit lighter. WITHOUT NEEDING TO LOOK FOR PROOF. And when depression comes thundering “NOOO I AM REALITY! YOU ARE KIDDING YOURSELF, YOUR VERY SOUL IS A LOSER SOUL”, just let it do it, but if you can, try not looking for proof of that either. Because the only reason you can find something that looks like proof, is because those things are self-fulfilling prophecies.

You have to decide that you trust it.

For example, I would sit down with a piece of paper, and write how I wanted things to be. “It’s no longer difficult for me to do things that are good for me. It just makes me happy. I am ready to leave the depression behind, and in fact that is not even going to be a choice. I no longer fear eye contact. It’s just as if that problem never existed.” All the time allowing myself to feel them as if they are true. If you feel that you can’t do it, it’s because you don’t want to trust it. You don’t believe in it. “This is delusional!”… Alright, fair enough. But so is the god damn depression! And as long as you insist that the depression is based in reality, and the positive thinking is just lying, then you’ve locked yourself into the basement and thrown away the key. Imagine if you believed constructive things as vehemently as you now believe the depression. That’s really the only difference between you now, and the alternate timeline where you are happy. And isn’t it far more interesting to have the audacity to look at your life, with absolute assuredness that all that has happened so far was good for you? You’ll be the only guy in the room with something different to say. And it’s all because no one allows themselves the easy-going rebellion of deciding what they want to believe.

Well, mushrooms and weed don’t just fix and break. Their lasting effects are patterns and emotions and behaviours. A fine grained awareness of how your thinking changed should be cultivated.

When I talk about looking for evidence, I’m talking about this phenomena: say you tell yourself that anything you do is genuinely the first piece of a master piece. Or that your medicated past does not affect you. Pr you can have any girl you want. There’s an instant rebuttal. Something inside of you will not let you trust those two statements. It wants proof! Because as far as it can tell, it’s just a lie. And it’s not safe to believe them, it may get you hurt or ridiculed. That’s what I mean.

But that proof will never come, because you have to trust and believe FIRST. Because life is like a bunch of rorschack tests interwoven. Some people see a butterfly, and some see a skull. When you add that up to a web of thousands of Rorschack tests, it seems like they are proof of eachother. We know VERY little, and so we create our lives by our beliefs about life and ourselves. And that goes DEEP. That’s the difference between Steve Jobs being Steve jobs, and Steve Jobs being a homeless drug addict.

As I said, it is an act of rebellion to simply start deciding what you want to believe, and deciding to let yourself trust it. That’s how you stop being incapacitated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28252140

Makeup is an art unto itself, if you do any kind of painting or really most visual art, a lot of concepts cross apply. You're effectively painting your face to make your features more attractive. There's tons of tutorials on YouTube to learn from.

If you're looking for professional wear, you need to get a sense of what that means for whatever you need it for. If it's a dress code for a job, you'll want to look at their standards and then meet them while putting your own twist to it. If instead you just want to have a more "mature" vibe to your wardrobe, there's a lot more room for exploration and figuring out what you like to wear.
Do you like skirts or pants? Long dresses? Etc.

A good starting place that I've found is that you'll want to have a lot of whatever suits your job and how you live. You want a lot of opportunities to wear stuff so that your "cost per wear" becomes really low. Thrifting is great for exploring how you want to dress and pushing your limits at low cost. It's hit or miss so you'll probably want to hit thrift stores weekly or so depending on how often they refresh stock.

In general, have fun with it. Try stuff on in stores, bring friends, don't spend a lot of money on anything super expensive til you get a sense of what brands are paying for quality vs. paying for the brand name.

>>28253166
>Female fashion seems rather chaotic, it doesn't seem to have the standards that male fashion has and that you can easily sit on.
As I bloke I'd disagree, the "chaos" stems from the more options available.

The fundamentals are the same, you wanna get the most out of the minimal amount of pieces of clothing. Buy basic, boring, timeless items of solid colours that you can dress up or dress down. For example, a neutral pair of pants, not in a slim cut but not too wide. A skirt that covers your knees, something that is modest but can be hitched up if needed. A buttoned blouse, which could be just as well be worn in an office, something that you can unbutton to reveal as much as you're comfortable with and can roll the sleeves up on to reveal arm accessories. A v-neck shirt, a pair of jeans, solid colour socks and underwear. A thin sweater you can layer on if it gets a bit chilly. Sensible clothes that provide utility.
Your most expensive items of clothing, just like a man's, oughta be the shoes and a coat. Women have the option of high heels on their feet, while their jackets can be a bit more bold with different cuts, shapes, colours and patterns.

Then you can fuck around with all the accessories. Nice jewellery, ribbons, hair ties, rings, piercings, nail paint, scarves, hats, pins, flowers.

Basically, unless you're doing some kooky runway show or are some massive whore that'd be just as happy running naked, you just have to try nail down the generic NPC look and change up one or two things that stand out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>> than when i stopped dieting

This is the problem. You're fat because you have a shit lifestyle. If you don't change the factors that made you fat in the first place what do you expect to happen?

You can't temporarily restrict calories then return to your previous lifestyle, and expect good things.

If you want to lose weight and keep it off you have to stop thinking about this as losing weight. Stop focusing on that, because it's a symptom not a cause. Treat causes.

The causes are

(1) You don't move around enough
(2) You don't have enough muscle
(3) You don't support your metabolism
(4) You eat like shit

In that order. Notice how food is down the bottom of the list? That's because it's factually the least important part of the equation. People just focus on it the most because it's the easiest to change.

If we want to lose weight and maintain that weight off though, we have to focus on points one and two. That means living a healthy, ACTIVE lifestyle. Even though it's self descriptive lots of people seem to not understand what active lifestyle means. It means, stop sitting down. Literally, you should only ever be sitting when absolutely necessary. Sitting is bad for you.

Instead you should be in almost constant motion. Walk or ride places instead of driving. Run places instead of walking. Take the stairs instead of the elevator. Walk up escalators and travelators, they aren't rides they're aids. Get involved in a team sport as one of your hobbies, congratulations you can now make friends whilst you fix your lifestyle.

Go out places. See things. Explore the world. Congratulations, now while you're fixing your lifestyle your life becomes richer, more enjoyable and meaningful. You also increased your chance of finding a romantic partner.

An active lifestyle is separate to exercise. Exercise is something you do in addition to an active lifestyle.

This leads us into point 2, muscle. Exercise to increase your fitness and muscle. Combined they [1/2]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
[2/2] increase metabolism. You'll ironically need to eat more to support your muscle growth.

But what you eat matters more than how much of it you eat. For this, follow the food pyramid. Eat in accordance to the pyramid, and check serving sizes on packets that you do buy. You'll be surprised by how small a serving is. Did you know a standard 50g packet of crisps contains 5 servings? We're talking 4 crisps in a serving.

posts.sub: How does someone move long distance?
posts.com:
I’ve been wanting to move from Ohio to Missouri for about a year. It was just a thought at first but have been seriously debating it with myself for the last few months. I just started a company I like working at, so Im able to save up some more money. How much should someone save in advance before moving a far distance? It’s just my dog and myself so at least it’s like Im trying to budget a whole family.
I used to have an apartment pre-covid but it didn’t work out well because I didn’t get as much work as I thought I would roofing and I wasn’t as smart with my money struggling to balance gas, rent, utilities, insurance all with less and less work. I had to move out the beginning of november 2021, moved back home and been here since.
My only friend here is in jail and I can’t stand to be around my extended family the way that my mother and brother are treated. My grandparents have money but I know that after my grandfather passes my grandmother is probably going to have my name removed from the will. When he passes Im taking the Winchester he’s leaving for me and going to Missouri as soon as possible.
Im tired of every day being told how my mother doesn’t know how to do anything from my grandmother. How my aunt is perfect and her boy is amazing, but my mother and her boys are just as worthless as they come. My grandfather is a good man that had his own business and 5 children. He was funny and could tell you a-z about Trees, farming, tractors, hunting, making money, saving money, a lot. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s around 2011, Parkinson’s 2021. He doesn’t have much longer left.

Read it or tell me to kill myself I just had to get it all out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28253137
Save up as much as you can.
the 50/30/20 rule for 50% on necessary expenses (rent and such), 30% for wants, and 20% for savings.
if you're at home, then your 50% is going to leave a lot leftover you can save, and depending on your hobbies, you can easily transfer more to the savings side so that it might end up being 20/20/60
From a different perspective, I think to be on the safe side, obviously get yourself the money to move. then 2-3 months ahead in rent, and also give yourself a bare minimum amount to live on per week if shit goes sour (maybe 300-400) and save that to be about 2 months worth.
you could move out without the safety net, just remember to build it up after the fact and keep adding to it.
that's at least a start. being smart with your money isn't hard on paper, but you have to be strict when your stack of savings starts to get bigger, and you're tempted to dip into it for something you want immediately.

It opened heaps of opportunities and pathways for me.

Bottom lime is, patterns of abuse need to be understood, they aren't random, they have causes, goals, they aren't the chaos they seem, and you can't escape them if you don't precisely know what you're dealing with.

Couple factors to look at when moving. University cities are usually "fun" because of all the young people, music that tours through, various restaurants, and usually some "cool" locally-owned businesses. They are also usually more leftwing in terms of city council and voter tendencies, so that effects the culture to be more about fun and less about strictly observing the bible.

Population density is important too for things like traffic and crowds at restaurants and grocery stores.

You want to move to a city or outlying area that has a current economy, or you will be living around very old people and really dumb people, working dairy queen and walmart jobs.

finally, unless you are incredibly driven to work hard in order to rise up and succeed, the top 15 most popular cities are a bad bet. You have to work your ass off in every industry to stand out because lots of people want to live there. I am talking things like restaurant work, hotel work, retail work. Lots of competition.

There are three ways to talk about normalcy here
>normal in the view of the law
>normal as a human being
>normal in the situation as you've described it.
The legal question's open and shut - you fuck that girl, the federal government and state of California both say you're a statutory rapist. The federal age of consent's 18 and when states disagree about age of consent, the higher age takes precedence. There's no Romeo in Juliet law in California anyway, so this means since you're 19 and she's underage, regardless of your personal opinion, from the state's perspective the relationship is abnormal and illegal.

Now, liking a 16 year old as a normal human being in the sense that you want to fuck them? That's pretty normal, at least broadly in the US, and the age of consent being 16 in most US states reflects this.

In the situation you've described though, separate from the legal question? It seems really abnormal. I think with this kind of age gap, your distance to the other person's is crucial for it to not be weird, and it gets weirder the more you have to go out of the way to make the relationship work. For example, if you were actively going to the same school when you started dating, I'd totally get it, that'd be a rising senior dating a sophomore. If you found out online that she lived in the same city as you, you met up, and you didn't know her age then? It'd be much weirder, but I could at least understand it. >>28253298
There are two plausible explanations (in my opinion):
First, those who cohabit are obviously more permissive towards relationships in general. That is, they are less likely to either take them seriously or aim to have a unique and lasting relationship with their spouse. Even if they claim to take relationships seriously, the fact is that they're willing to be intimate without commitment and with multiple people (because the point of cohabiting for the ones who claim it's out of seriousness is to test compatibility--presumably so they can cohabit again if they find something they don't like). That such people are also more willing to leave a relationship isn't surprising, since everything they do reflects a mindset that doesn't prioritize commitment.

Second, cohabiting creates inertia. If you've already been living together, mingling finances, and even had kids before getting married, you've made it much easier to slide into a marriage you never really wanted in the first place, because a formal marriage doesn't change much. Whereas if you live apart and don't do anything reckless (like having a kid out of wedlock), getting married is very much a conscious commitment and a major change in one's life on its own. It's much harder to just sleepwalk into a marriage this way.

>Do you think it's because the former group probably tends to be religious and therefore already biased against divorce
Not primarily, no. The "religious, therefore no divorce" argument is simplistic and often just wrong. Religions DO tend to emphasize following certain rules, like sexual restraint, which just so happen to improve the outcomes of the relationships people have. The effect holds even after controlling for religion: those who wait until marriage both divorce less AND have happier marriages. Not just a matter of miserable couples not divorcing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28253321
Across all years examined in this study, the odds of divorce were 1.31 times higher for women who cohabitated prior to marriage.

Cohabitation may confer "short-term benefits" in the sense that divorce risk is lower for these couples right after the wedding (within the first 6 months) and slightly lower in the subsequent 6 months. During that initial year, couples that did not live together first are at higher risk for divorce. Maybe cohabitators have less of an abrupt transition after marriage, and this gives them an initial advantage. However, the tide turns after that first year, and people who cohabitated before marriage end up having elevated risk relative to those who did not.

had a crazy motorcycle accident a year ago and have been doing some writing to try to let the past go

In the process i found that i held onto most of my past, school failures, social failures, getting bullied, evictions, failures on failures. it got to a point where i just was in survival mode and didnt want to try anything at all.

It was actually the short time before i bought that motorcycle where i started to believe in myself, to try new things. so when i got into that accident and scared the bejesus out of my family, i felt like i was being punished by the universe. it truly truly felt like i was not allowed to breathe, and i was allowed to keep my health after the crash as a warning of sorts.

learned today that that line of thinking is actually just PTSD and im not alone. that people who suffer from near miss experiences and other types of traumatic events often have trouble trying to get their brains to just not hyperfixate on the why's and what if's.

my dad is suddenly sick and might have colon cancer, it's a big maybe for now. nothing confirmed. but as i get older, these sorts of things just come one after the other.

>why am i alive?
>why do i get to live on?
>maybe it was a mistake and i was supposed to die?
>if i get another motorcycle, will the universe punish me again for it?
>what does the universe want me to do so i can avoid punishment?
>if my dad dies tomorrow, does that mean i did something wrong again, or am i still paying for my crimes?

what were my crimes? surely i committed something so heinous that i was given these punishments. Or was it that i exist, and that with existence comes pain and loss.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Walk it whenever you're home. That usually tires them out well into the next day

Maybe your dog breed is not sutable for your living arrangements now. Dogs get needy. Consider training

There are a few toys that can keep a dog busy whenever hes anxious. Be it flavorful bones, hard toys with frozen peanut butter in them, or just some spazzy cheap toys with lights and shit. Have them laying around.

You can arrange it so a friend comes and hangs out with your dog from time to time.

Medication should be one of your last resorts, but dont be afraid of using it. It makes the transition from anxious dog to trained-to-be-relaxed pup easier, but it isnt a clutch. You need to train it at some level.
